source.e3b4376e:
counts,bin_edges=np.histogram(setosa["PetalLengthCm"],bins=10,density=True)
pdf=counts/sum(counts)
cdf=np.cumsum(pdf)
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:],pdf)
plt.plot(bin_edges[1:],cdf)
plt.title("iris-setosa")
plt.xlabel("Petal Length")
plt.ylabel("frequency")
source.a2b86f24:
counts,bins_edges=np.histogram(versicolor["PetalLengthCm"],bins=10,density=True)
pdf=counts/sum(counts)
cdf=np.cumsum(pdf)
plt.plot(bins_edges[1:],pdf)
plt.plot(bins_edges[1:],cdf)
plt.title("iris-versicolor")
plt.xlabel("Petal Length")
plt.ylabel("Frequency")
plt.show()

source.4451fb58:
## Exploratory Data Analysis

#### Univariate
Univariate analysis
Univariate analysis is the simplest form of analyzing data. “Uni” means “one”, so in other words your data has only one variable. It doesn’t deal with causes or relationships (unlike regression) and it’s major purpose is to describe; it takes data, summarizes that data and finds patterns in the data.

similar to Box Plot but with a rotated plot on each side, giving more information about the density estimate on the y-axis. advantage of a violin plot is that it can show nuances in the distribution that aren’t perceptible in a boxplot
#### violin plot=boxplot+ histogarm #### squares are box plot and white dot indicates 50% percentile. #### curves are nothing but distribution curves.

source.b6a83b49:
## PDF and CDF
Now we will calculate Pdf and Cdf for Petal Length for all 3 species.
Distribution plots for Pdf and cdf are used to visually assess how the data points are distributed with respect to its frequency.
Usually the data points are grouped into bins and the height of the bars representing each group increases with increase in the number of data points 
lie within that group. (histogram)
